title: vital find trusted messengers spread vaccine information   dr amir khan
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityDr Khan was speaking as he volunteered at a vaccination centre in Leeds as part of his new role as the first-ever ambassador for the Leeds Hospitals Charity.ldquoI think itrsquos really important that people from all backgrounds come forward for the vaccine and there has been a certain amount of increased hesitancy from people from minority backgrounds, he told the PA news agency at Leeds Unitedrsquos Elland Road ground.Irsquom volunteering at the Leeds Covid Vaccination Centre today as part of my exciting new role as an ambassador for the @LDShospcharityHopefully helping to raise money and awareness for great local NHS causes!! pic KiRgtTwIrUmdash Dr Amir Khan GP #March , ldquoThe reasons for that are really complex and historical.ldquoWe want the right information to get out there.ldquoWe want people to get information from the right sources. And itrsquos a constant battle. I donrsquot think wersquore there yet.ldquoIf you look at the statistics, people from black communities in particular are less likely to come forward for the vaccine.ldquoWe really need to make sure they get the right information because theyrsquove been hit really hard through this pandemic and we owe it to them to get them the right information and get them vaccinated. vw,vw,px, px"Good Morning Britain doctor Dr Amir Khan during a tour of the Elland Road vaccine centre in Leeds Dr Khan, who lives in Leeds and works at a GP practice in Bradford, said he has now had both his vaccine shots and is hoping his example will encourage people from a South Asian background to take up the invitation.He said: ldquoPeople from these communities want to see people who look like themselves in the media and want to see them talking about this.ldquoAnd they want to see them reassuring them about what their worries around the vaccines are.ldquoIt doesnrsquot mean it has to be doctors or nurses. It could be faith leaders or other community leaders who they have trust in. Itrsquos finding those people and getting them to say the right things which will prove vital in this.ldquoIf they see those guys getting vaccinated, theyrsquore far more likely to get vaccinated.Dr Khan first appeared on the Channel  TV series GPs: Behind Closed Doors and is now well-known for regular appearances on ITVrsquos Lorraine and Good Morning Britain.He said: ldquoIt is an absolute privilege to be joining Leeds Hospitals Charity as their first-ever ambassador.ldquoBeing from Yorkshire, and working within the NHS myself, I can see first-hand the great support these charities title: oxford island play park refurbishment approved
story: Motorcyclist dies in two vehicle collision in NI town   Community rallies to help young family left homeless after fireNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPoliticsOxford Island play park refurbishment approvedA proposal to upgrade the play park near the Lough Neagh Discovery Centre at Oxford Island has been approved by Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council’s planning committee.By The NewsroomThursday, th March , : pm  "       "  The application to refurbish the play park m west south west of Lough Neagh Discovery Centre on the Annaloiste Road, Lurgan, was brought before the committee as it is a Council owned site.The application sought approval to refurbish the existing play park with an extension to the site area, removal of existing equipment, bins, seating and furniture and replace them with new bitmac and wetpour surfacing, fencing, play equipment, bins and street furniture.Members of the committee were made aware the existing play park at the proposed site is . hectares in size and the proposed site also includes a portion of grassed area that is approximately . hectares in size."The existing play park is bounded by a low post and wire fence approximatelym in height and there is a public footpath separatingthe park from a forest and trees to the west and a public footpath separatingthe site to the south.The adjacent water feature will remain unchanged.Members were also made aware the proposed play equipment and street furniture is of an improved quality and provides access for people with disabilities.The new proposal includes  pieces of play equipment including bespoke timber play equipment for the site on a new bound rubber safety surface. The proposal also includes  sun seats and three picnic tables."There will be new pathways to access the site and a new .m high chestnutpale perimeter fence.There will be no change to pedestrianor vehicular movementas a result of this development. Members were advised the existing nature reserve, marina and park already attract a signicant number of visitors and there are existing pedestrian and cycle linkages.The planning office responsible for the case confirmed the officer’s recommendation was to approve the application.The Chair of the committee, Councillor Darren McNally noted the wooded area to one side of the play park and asked how it was secured. He was advised there will be a .m high fence around the play area.Councillor Tim McClelland askedofficers were content the parking provision remains adequate at the site.The planning officer advised the Department for Infrastructure had been consulted and accepted that this new attraction may well increase visitor numbers but said despite this, officers are content with the number of spaces available.Alderman Kenneth Twyble said both he and Councillor Declan McAlinden represent this area and described the Lough Neagh Discovery Centre and its surroundings as “the jewel in our crown”.“I think this is wonderful and we must give it our total support,” said Alderman Twyble.“There is a y road down to it but that is part of the facilities. This is a welcome piece of good news for the area.”Councillor Ciaran Toman askeda safety barrier had been considered for users of the park and his question was answered by Alderman Twyble who informed him there was a one-way system in operation and the paths keep people separatefrom vehicles.Councillor Declan McAlinden said the redevelopment of this play park would be an “excellent addition to what is already there”.and proposed the recommendation to approve the planning application.This proposal was seconded by Alderman Twyble and the committee voiced its agreement.Call for action over troubled GP Practice - read hereEditor’s message:Thank you for reading this article. stFermanagh and Omagh District Councilrsquos St Patrickrsquos Festival plans finalisedReporter: Name Last NameWednesday  March  :PREPARATIONS are at an advanced stage for Fermanagh and Omagh District Council’s St Patrick’s Festival  which takes place this year from Friday, March  to . The Festival, launched recently by the chair of the council, councillor Diana Armstrong, while dferent in nature to previous events, will be one of the largest and most ambitious virtual programmes undertaken by Fermanagh and Omagh District Council. Councillor Armstrong said: The programme is a rich and ied celebration of all that is good about St Patrick’s Day and while it is certainly dferent to previous years, it still affords us the opportunity to celebrate in a connected and positive way.” A full programme of virtual entertainment featuring music, dance, storytelling and arts and crafts will be live streamed from the Ardhowen and Strule Arts Centre. There is something for everyone with music from the Tumbling Paddies, Cliona Hagan, The Drunken Lullabies and The Logues to name but a few. Arts and Crafts sessions are also programmed together with storytelling in both English and Irish and a session of Folk Tales from Fermanagh.  ‘The Story of Saint Patrick’, a short film charting Saint Patrick’s le from his abduction at the age of  to hisas an adult bringing Christianity to the local population was launched on the council’s social media channels on Tuesday, March . The popular St Patrick’s Festival Primary Schools art exhibition s again this year, albeit virtually and will be launched on Friday, March . A number of virtual community initiatives, supported by Fermanagh and Omagh District Council, will take place across the district as part of the Festival. NameThursday  March  :PRE-school, nursery and primary schools pupils in P to P will remain in school until the start of the Easter break. The decision, which was agreed by the Executive today, means that the youngest pupils will continue with face-to-face teaching for the remainder of this term. Decisions on the timing for theof other primary and post-primary pupils will be considered next Tuesday as part of an overall review of the current restrictions. Students in years  to , who will be awarded qualication results this summer, willto full time face-to face teaching with effect from March , . Education Minister Peter Weir said: “I welcome the decision by the Executive today to allow the youngest pupils to continue with face-to-face teaching until the start of the Easter holidays. “I know that many schools, parents and other pupils want clarity on when more year groups will be ing. I will continue to make the case for all pupils toas soon as practicably possible and in line with public health advice and scientic evidence. “It is clear that long periods away from the classroom has a signicant impact on the mental health and well-being of our children and young people. Remote learning, no matter how well provided and delivered, is no replacement for face-to-face learning and educational experience. I am particularly conscious of the disproportionate impact that this has on disadvantaged groups and vulnerable children.”  addthis,     Leave your commentTyrone Constitution- High Street, OmaghBT
